Award.AwardTitle: Large-scale Terrane Displacement in the Arctic: Evidence from Faults in the Northern Yukon
Award.AbstractNarration:
The shapes of the continents are modified over time by a variety of tectonic processes including large-scale horizontal transport of crustal fragments. This project explores the idea that this process was important in shaping the current configuration of the North American Arctic region. The research team will investigate a major fault system - the Kaltag-Porcupine fault system - in northern Yukon, Canada to determine if it accommodated horizontal movement of a large portion of the Arctic region and, if so, when this occurred. This research project will not only further our understanding of large-scale transport of crustal fragments along continent-scale strike-slip systems, but also provide new insights into the tectonic evolution of the poorly understood Arctic region of North America, a region important for its natural resources. The study will promote international collaboration between academic researchers at two U.S. institutions, two Canadian and German universities, and government research agencies in both Germany, Canada, and the United States. The collaborative international effort will also generate research opportunities and training for undergraduate and graduate students at both Dartmouth College and the University of Iowa, as well as a series of public lectures and a new museum exhibit in the Upper Valley of New England.

Recent models for the Paleozoic tectonic evolution of the Arctic highlight significant, yet poorly understood, margin-parallel transport of crustal fragments relative to the North American craton; however, very little is known about the hypothetical structures that accommodated these displacements. The goal of this research project is to study the Kaltag-Porcupine fault system of Yukon, Canada, a craton-bounding structure that potentially accommodated the displacement of Arctic Alaska and other Arctic terranes across the northern margin of Laurentia. The fault system was probably reactivated during the Mesozoic and Tertiary, but may be a much older early Paleozoic structure. The research team aims to determine if the structure separates geologic units with different histories and paleogeographic origins and if there is any evidence for Paleozoic displacement on the structure. This project will involve: 1) development of a large, stratigraphically-constrained provenance data set, consisting of sandstone petrography, large-N detrital zircon U/Pb geochronology and hafnium isotopes, and major and trace element geochemistry and neodymium isotopes on mudstone, from previously collected and new samples of late Neoproterozoic-Silurian strata in the North Slope subterrane and Yukon block of northwestern Canada; and 2) a detailed structural and geochronological examination of the Kaltag-Porcupine fault system in northern Yukon, Canada. This multidisciplinary project will fundamentally inform tectonic models for the evolution of the Arctic and northwestern margin of North America.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focused on studying the fault system that separates a displaced crustal fragment, referred to as the Arctic Alaska terrane, and the northwestern North American margin in Yukon and Alaska. The Porcupine shear zone juxtaposes sedimentary and volcanic rocks of the Arctic Alaska terrane with North American units, but the timing and magnitude of displacement have long been contentious. The project focused on (1) structural and geochronologic analysis of deformed rocks within the fault zone to establish the displacement history and (2) combined stratigraphic, geochronologic, geochemical and paleontological studies to characterize variations or similarities in Precambrian to Triassic units across the tectonic boundary.  Collectively, the research examined the timing and magnitude of displacement on the Porcupine shear zone and the role of the structure in the tectonic evolution of northwestern North America. Fieldwork for the project was conducted during 3 transects along the Porcupine River in Alaska and Yukon during 2017-2019. The project involved a post-doctoral scholar, two graduate students and 4 undergraduate students at the University of Iowa and mentoring and collaboration with 2 graduate and several undergraduate students from Dartmouth College.

 

Major research outcomes of the project include:

 1) The Porcupine shear zone records a complex and long history of strike-slip displacement that includes both left-lateral and right-lateral sense of shear in mid-Paleozoic and Mesozoic time. The structure is a major crustal boundary that accommodated Paleozoic translation of the Arctic Alaska terrane along the northern margin of North America and likely played a critical role in the Mesozoic opening of the Canada Basin.    

2) The Porcupine fault system separates displaced Neoproterozoic to Devonian units of the North Slope subterrane of Arctic Alaska from low-grade Mesoproterozoic?Paleozoic rocks of the Yukon block on the northwestern North American margin. The detrital zircon isotopic signature of the North Slope subterrane units is distinct from the Yukon Block but similar to coeval units of the Franklinian Basin, indicating the subterrane originated on or near the northeastern Arctic margin of North America in proximity to Greenland and Ellesmere Island, Canada.

3) Evolution of the Porcupine shear zone occurred during and in response to assembly of the Arctic Alaska terrane from multiple peri-Laurentian and peri-Baltic crustal fragments and juxtaposition with northern Laurentian margin in the middle Paleozoic. The Porcupine shear zone is the western continuation of the major crustal-scale strike-slip zone responsible for left-lateral translation of the Pearya terrane on northern Ellesmere Island.

 

4) The Apoon assemblage of the Arctic Alaska terrane represents a juvenile Ordovician?Devonian arc complex that is similar to the southern Alexander terrane in the North American Cordillera. These arc fragments originated in an early Paleozoic convergent boundary representing the northern continuation of the Taconic?Caledonian arc system between northeastern Laurentia and Baltica. The Porcupine shear zone represents an important strand of the fault system that facilitated Paleozoic terrane translation and transfer from the Caledonian to the Cordilleran orogens. 

The project contributed to the development of international relations by fostering collaborations between several academic institutions (University of Iowa, Dartmouth College, University of Erlangen) and government agencies (Yukon Geological Survey, U.S. Geological Survey). Significant opportunities in STEM training and education have been provided as well. University of Iowa personnel supported by the project include female M.S. student, a Veteran M.S. student and 4 female undergraduate students.  Collaboration with field and geochronologic research of Ph.D. and undergraduate students from Dartmouth College has been provided by this project. The project supported publication of a Geological Society of America Special Paper volume, six peer-reviewed manuscripts, eight public presentations at conferences and a M.S. thesis at the University of Iowa.
